text: <@UPMFG2571> Sorry, no references. I know these systems as a user, not as an academic.

elements.text: Sorry, no references. I know these systems as a user, not as an academic.

text:
Humans communicate in a context of shared abstractions. In programming we create formalizations for abstractions. Not sure this is comparable.
This reminds me of a long-ago discussion with colleagues about teaching mathematical concepts in physics. Is it better to start from examples and then develop abstractions, or start with the abstract and then introduce examples for illustration? There were good arguments on both sides.

elements.text:
Humans communicate in a context of shared abstractions. In programming we create formalizations for abstractions. Not sure this is comparable.
This reminds me of a long-ago discussion with colleagues about teaching mathematical concepts in physics. Is it better to start from examples and then develop abstractions, or start with the abstract and then introduce examples for illustration? There were good arguments on both sides.

text: Curiously, no particular paper stands out in my mind.  The only academic insight that I have is that the semantics of how state responds to a change in definition corresponds to an ordering of monads.  And I only remember this faintly as a good example of how monads don't commute (as a rule) and why one shouldn't be too disappointed.
